item.title: Suspect in Benghazi Attack Is Arraigned in U.S.
item.description: The militia leader Ahmed Abu Khattala pleaded not guilty Saturday in federal court in Washington to charges stemming from the 2012 attack on the United States mission in which four Americans died.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The motorcade transporting the Libyan militia leader Ahmed Abu Khattala left the federal courthouse in Washington on Saturday.

item.title: Revelry in Sarajevo, Where Shots Started a World War
item.description: There was much about Sarajevo that spoke for a less reflective mood on the 100th anniversary of the deaths of Archduke Franz Ferdinand and his wife, Sophie.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: A man waved a Serbian flag as a crowd gathered to hear a band play in Visegrad on Saturday.

item.title: Obama to Seek Funds to Stem Border Crossings and Speed Deportations
item.description: President Obama will seek $2 billion for border enforcement to cope with the influx of illegal Central American migrants, including unprecedented numbers of unaccompanied minors.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Joshua Lott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators outside a federal building in Detroit on Saturday spoke up about deportations.

item.title: Despite High Unemployment, Portugal Looks Far Afield for Workers
item.description: A low minimum wage and relatively generous unemployment benefits make tough agricultural labor a hard sell, so companies import workers from as far away as Thailand.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreria for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers harvesting and packaging berries at Maravilha Farms in Odemira, Portugal, this month.

item.title: 11 Die in India as Buildings Collapse
item.description: Two buildings more than 1,000 miles apart, one in Chennai and the other in New Delhi, fell within hours of each other on Saturday, trapping construction workers.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: A Reversal by a Militia of Rwandan Hutus in Democratic Republic of Congo
item.description: The gesture is a new twist in a war that has pitted Central African tribes and nations against one another for 20 years, but officials are skeptical of the militants’ intentions.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Sarah Fluck for The New York Times
item.media:description: Boys in Kigogo, Democratic Republic of Congo, watched this month as Rwandan militants turned in their weapons. It was the biggest celebration many villagers had known.

item.title: Argentina’s Vice President Charged in Corruption Case
item.description: Vice President Amado Boudou has been charged with bribery and conducting business incompatible with public office in the acquisition of the company that prints the country’s currency.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: If convicted, Vice President Amado Boudou could be sentenced to one to six years in prison and barred from elective office.

item.title: A Reignited War Drives Iraqis Out in Huge Numbers
item.description: Iraqis have fled their homes in recent weeks, filled with fear and uncertainty — and a painful sense of familiarity. More than a million Iraqis have been displaced this year, and for many it was not the first time.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Listening Post: With Surge of Chaos in Iraq, a Familiar Problem Knocks on Biden’s Door
item.description: Recent events in Iraq could vindicate an idea advanced by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in 2006: to split the country into three largely autonomous regions.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a World Cup game on June 16. The president called a meeting on Iraq that same day.

item.title: Once a Militant Stronghold in Iraq, Now a Battleground Again
item.description: The village of al-Daira lies in an area the American military once called the Triangle of Death. Militants are now pressuring Baghdad by trying to sever Iraq’s principal highway.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: Dispatch: Britain’s Strange Identity Crisis
item.description: The vote on Scotland’s referendum to stay in or leave the United Kingdom will bring major change, either way.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Who Is Setting the Sectarian Fires in the Middle East?
item.description: Some argue that it is not inevitable that the Middle East erupt in sectarian conflagration.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN
item.media:description: A scene from Aleppo, Syria, after airstrikes by government forces in March. Some argue that the sectarian violence in the region isn’t necessarily inevitable.

item.title: News Analysis: Life in Iraq Grinds On, Whoever Is in Charge
item.description: Whether Shiites or ISIS is in charge, residents just want to live their lives.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GLANZ
item.media:credit: Robert Nickelsberg/Getty Images for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pool hall in Husayba, Iraq, near the Syrian border, in 2007.

item.title: Opinion: China’s Threat to Wild Tigers
item.description: A luxury market in skins, meat and wine endangers the rare cat.
item.dc:creator: By SHARON GUYNUP

item.title: ArtsBeat: Bolshoi Director Attacked With Acid Returns to Hospital
item.description: Sergei Filin, the Bolshoi Ballet’s artistic director who was nearly blinded in an acid attack last year, is in intensive care at a Moscow hospital, Russian news agencies reported Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By ROSLYN SULCAS

item.title: Sports of The Times: World Cup 2014: Residents Wonder How New Stadiums Will Benefit Region After Cup
item.description: Billed as a boon to Brazil, gleaming new stadiums rose for the World Cup — but now residents wonder how they will benefit after the last goal is scored.
item.dc:creator: By JULIET MACUR
item.media:description: Maria Ivanilde Oliveira in her home, which is across a highway from Arena das Dunas in Natal, Brazil. The $450 million used to build it “could have been spent on better things,” she said.

item.title: Iraq’s Sunni Militants Take to Social Media to Advance Their Cause and Intimidate
item.description: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria has demonstrated modern sophistication in its adoption of social media, particularly Twitter, where its hashtags have gained jihadist followers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Family Kills Pakistani Couple After They Married for Love
item.description: The couple, a 17-year-old girl and a 31-year-old man, who were married on June 18 in Pakistan without the consent of their families, were killed by the girl’s family.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: In New Show of Force, Iraqi Army Drives Back Insurgents in Major City
item.description: Iraqi forces drove militants from the center of Tikrit, partly reversing the advance of insurgents who had come within 50 miles of Baghdad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and SUADAD AL-SALHY
item.media:description: Shiite militia members on Saturday in the desert region between Kerbala and Baghdad.

item.title: Leslie Manigat, Ousted as Haiti Leader, Dies at 83
item.description: Mr. Manigat was overthrown in a bloodless military coup after serving less than six months in office.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PACE

item.title: Abdullah Abdullah and 15,000 Protesters Gathered in Kabul
item.description: Tension seemed amplified in a second demonstration in support of Abdullah Abdullah, who has complained of widespread ballot fraud in the recent presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Kabul on Friday to protest electoral fraud in the recent presidential election.

item.title: Saudi King Promises Help in Delicate Effort to Unite Factions in Iraq
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry enlisted the support of the monarch, as well as a Syrian opposition leader, for a multi-sect government.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, in Jeddah on Friday.

item.title: Syria: Dispute Unsettles Rebel Coalition
item.description: The interim government said that it would fire the head of the Supreme Military Council of the Free Syrian Army and refer its members to a commission investigating corruption.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Taliban Mount Major Assault in Afghanistan
item.description: The group has attacked police outposts and government facilities in several districts of northern Helmand Province, sending the police and military officials scrambling to shore up defenses.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Workers at Iraq Power Plant Said to be Headed to Safety
item.description: More than 1,000 Chinese workers at a power plant north of Baghdad were evacuated to the capital city after previous attempts to move them to safety had failed, reports say.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
